Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2009 01:08AM theprettiestmess wrote: Absolutely! The only infusion I DIDN'T drive myself to was the first one, because no one knew how I was going to react to the myriad of drugs that would be used! I had Benadryl in each of my 15 infusions, and if I can offer you one bit of advice: TAKE THE NAP!! I didn't fight it while I was hooked up, and it was the most wonderful 3 hour nap! By the time I was ready to be flushed, I was wide awake from the steroids! In my particular chemo "cocktail", I was given Tagamet and Benadryl via IV, and a push of Aloxi, which is an anti-nausea medication. I also had a prescription for Emend, which I took one hour prior to my appointment and one each day after for the next two days. I had prescriptions for Zofran and phenergan to combat any nausea afterward, but I didn't ever have any. Don't look at chemo as poison. Look at it as medicine that's working hard to make you well! Get friendly with your oncology nurses. I think that the average length of time for infusions is around 3-3 1/2 hours, plus any exam you might have. When you get home, do yourself a favor and rest, if your body is telling you to. You'll recover so much better if you don't fight yourself! Good Luck! Robin
Posts.Title: Can you drive yourself to chemo appointments? arnie SoCalLisa

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2009 12:47PM theprettiestmess wrote: I will miss Lydia...we would go and have breakfast together (as well as a few other women who have been battling breast cancer)...her spirit was always phenomenal. I'm envisioning her, up in heaven, having a little sit down with God, telling him that he needs to wipe out cancer from everyone. She's there, always in our corner. I love you, Lydia... Ron and family, please know that you all have my prayers and my deepest sympathies.
Posts.Title: Luv2Travel is an Angel now LuAnnH BonnieVA

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2008 05:55PM theprettiestmess wrote: I'm in the second phase of chemo, first was FAC, now it's weekly Taxol (9 more left). I've not gained any weight, but I've maintained. My pants size has also gone down a size even though I get a bag of Decadron in my pre-med drip. Maybe it's the type of steroid/chemo cocktail that is the decider...all I know is that  my clothes are getting looser, and the scale remains the same.
Posts.Title: weight gain during chemo??? rayhope theprettiestmess

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2009 02:24AM theprettiestmess wrote: I didn't have any side effects, really, from the adriamycin or cytoxan, aside from my hair falling out 13 days after my first round of AC, and my heartrate went up (which doesn't happen to everyone). Adriamycin CAN damage heart valves, but it doesn't happen to everyone...you'll be monitored... Cytoxan gave me a funky, fizzy feeling in my brain during the infusion...sorta like if you're swimming and got water up your nose...that burning feeling...but that was just me! YMMV! Drink Drink Drink!!  Take your anti-nausea meds, too, if you've gotten a scrip for Emend, that's a lifesaver! No nausea for me at all! Good luck, and we'll be praying for you! Robin
Posts.Title: AC Triciaski Triciaski

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2009 01:15AM theprettiestmess wrote: My tale: I completed 12 Taxol (not taxotere), and didn't have anything happen to my finger/toenails at all. No neuropathy either. I kept up with my own nail maintenance with polish and topcoat without any issues whatsoever!  Don't get worked up about everything we all read...because everyone's story is gonna be different! Robin
Posts.Title: Finger/fingernail problems? How common? Texas357 Texas357

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2009 04:52AM theprettiestmess wrote: Hi Ladies! I hope I'm not intruding on you...I'm coming from the Chemo Sept 08 group. I finished 4 FAC and 12 Taxol mid Feb and I wanted to tell you all some things that you cannot buy that will help you get through chemo.  Positive attitude is EVERYTHING. SMILE!! Yes, you may feel nauseous...that's why your onc gave you prescriptions for Emend (take it!), Zofran (take it!) and Phenergan (take it!) to GET AHEAD of any potential nausea. Don't think of chemo as "poison"...think of it as "medicine". Make friends with those that are sitting next to you while you're getting your infusion...Make friends with the onc nurses, too!  It makes the time go by faster.  Don't be afraid to speak up if something feels funky. Don't be afraid to ask for an anti-depressant or an anti-anxiety medication to help you get through it...you're human. Everyone will react (or not) to treatment differently. Not everyone will lose their hair or have their fingernails/toenails turning black and fall off.  Remember that you're still beautiful, even though your hair is falling out in clumps, your brows and lashes fall out, your bones hurt, and your sense of taste has taken a six month vacation.  We are amazing creatures, ladies. Every week, we get potentially lethal doses of toxic chemicals pumped into our bodies, and we are still standing, walking, loving, and fighting!! YOU CAN DO THIS!!! Remember that the ones that really understand what you're going through, the women (and men) you meet HERE will be the ones you go to on a daily basis. Lean on them. Love them. Pray with and for them. They are your sisters. Find a church, and if you have one, let them know that you have breast cancer. The support that will flow out of there will astonish you. Pray.  Sing. Accept help when it's offered. Say "No" if you can't do something...and know that it's ok. Don't wallow in self pity...it's not pretty, and it won't get you anywhere! You're in for the fight of your life...you are going to beat this beast, and come out on top!  Remind yourself every day, in the mirror, in your car...I AM A WARRIOR!! Breathe it. LIVE it.  Know that we're all here for you, to pray with you, cry with you, love you, and kick you in the panties when you're feeling sorry for yourself. All you need to do is reach out. We'll be there. Loving each of you... Robin

Even though your marks line up as they should, your breast tissue may not be where they need it to be.

Posts.Title: Oncotype Dx test... Harley44 123JustMe

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2008 09:23PM theprettiestmess wrote: My "cord" ran from my SNB site, down on the right side of by breast, and MAN, did it hurt! I saw my oncologist, and she said that it was a clot in a superficial vein that was damaged during the SNB. She had me take an 80mg aspirin every day to break it up. Took about two weeks. No more cord, no more pain!

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2008 11:45AM theprettiestmess wrote: I  hear that! Ha! He's coming for the weekend...this will be the first time he's seen me since before I had my lumpectomy, re-excision and SNB...all I can say is that he'd better watch his toes.... Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2008 02:26PM theprettiestmess wrote: I had my lumpectomy a week ago Thursday, and I had a re-excision this past Thursday along with a SNB. My incision looked clean, and he went back into the same incision this time, I am fairly large breasted and I hate sleeping in a bra, but I found a sports bra locally that was comfortable enough. I won't go out in public, though... I'm not into the one boob in the middle of my chest look!  I also had a reaction to the surgical tape..blistered and itchy! This time I had a id band that stated "no surgical tape"!   Robin
